title: Travel Alberta apologizes for an advertisement featuring a map of Canada missing the border lines for Nunavut
text:
Top celebrity tourism campaigns 
Alberta's tourism marketing agency is apologizing for overlooking Canada's largest territory. 
In a June advertisement promoting the ease and affordability of travelling to Alberta from major American cities such as Los Angeles, Houston and Chicago, the map of Canada used by Travel Alberta is missing the border lines for Nunavut. 
The advertisement was posted to the popular link-sharing site Reddit on Monday where it was heavily mocked by users under the title "This Travel Alberta ad forgot Nunavut exists". 
"It is disappointing," said Ipeelie Ootoova, manager of the Arctic Coast Visitor Centre in Cambridge Bay, a hamlet located on Victoria Island in the Kitikmeot region of Nunavut that's famous for its fishing and archaeological sites. 
"A lot of people don't know anything about Nunavut, how we live, our culture, even if they're Canadian so I think it should be shown everywhere," he said. 
"They shouldn't be leaving it as part of the Northwest Territories. We've been a territory since 1999, that's sixteen years. It's the newest territory in Canada. I don't get why it's left off." 
The centre receives many tourist visits with five major passenger cruise ships stopping in Cambridge Bay during the summer, said Ootoova, but many visitors lack knowledge about Nunavut's history and culture. He said more education about Nunavut is needed and leaving it off a map of the country doesn't help. 
Wildrose tourism critic Ron Orr said the artistically-rendered map "disregards aboriginal and Inuit status and disregards the status of Nunavut itself" and criticized the agency's "bloated bureaucracy" for not catching the error before print. 
Travel Alberta promptly admitted the design error and apologized on Monday. 
"It was an error on our end and we do apologize if it causes any concern or confusion for anyone. We are correcting the imagery to ensure it doesn't happen again," said spokesperson Jennifer Anderson. 
Anderson couldn't say how widely the advertisement was circulated but said the map was included as part of a ten-page "call to action" showcasing Alberta's major tourism destinations in the June edition of United Airlines' Hemisphere Magazine. 
"We hope that our tourism friends in Nunavut understand this was a mistake and we're going to be reaching out to them as well," she said. "We want to always ensure the accuracy of our marketing." 
Travel Alberta is the tourism marketing agency of the Government of Alberta that is governed by the Travel Alberta Act and a Board of Directors accountable to the Minister of Culture and Tourism.
